properties.name: Hel Peninsula (Poland)
properties.description: Amber often washes up along the beaches between Władysławowo and Hel, especially after storms.

properties.name: Gdańsk – Amber Capital (Poland)
properties.description: Historic amber trading city with nearby beaches where amber can still be found.

properties.name: Jantar Beach (Poland)
properties.description: Named after amber itself ('jantar' means amber); known for frequent finds.

properties.name: Palanga Beach (Lithuania)
properties.description: Amber can be found on this Baltic Sea beach, especially after storms; home to the Amber Museum.

properties.name: Jūrmala (Latvia)
properties.description: Resort town near Riga; amber occasionally washes up along the sandy coast.

properties.name: Blåvand Beach (Denmark)
properties.description: Excellent amber-hunting beach; finders often visit after winter storms.

properties.name: Rømø Island (Denmark)
properties.description: Wide sandy beaches where amber is found mixed with seaweed; popular with hobbyists.

properties.name: Sankt Peter-Ording (Germany)
properties.description: Amber sometimes found along this North Sea coast, especially after storms.

properties.name: Binz, Rügen Island (Germany)
properties.description: Baltic Sea island known for natural amber and fossil finds along the beach.

properties.name: Usedom Island (Germany/Poland border)
properties.description: Amber occasionally washes ashore on this island; accessible from Świnoujście.

properties.name: Skagen (Denmark, northern tip)
properties.description: Amber can sometimes be found where the North and Baltic Seas meet.

properties.name: Sopot Beach (Poland)
properties.description: Tourist beach between Gdańsk and Gdynia; occasional amber finds.

properties.name: Ventspils Beach (Latvia)
properties.description: Wide sandy beach with occasional amber pieces, especially after storms.

properties.name: Niechorze Beach (Poland)
properties.description: Baltic Sea coast west of Kołobrzeg; amber sometimes found after storms.
